How Bad is Training on Synthetic Data? A Statistical Analysis of Language Model Collapse

Abstract

The phenomenon of model collapse, introduced in (Shumailov et al., 2023), refers to the deterioration in performance that occurs when new models are trained on synthetic data generated from previously trained models. This recursive training loop makes the tails of the original distribution disappear, thereby making future-generation models forget about the initial (real) distribution. With the aim of rigorously understanding model collapse in language models, we consider in this paper a statistical model that allows us to characterize the impact of various recursive training scenarios. Specifically, we demonstrate that model collapse cannot be avoided when training solely on synthetic data. However, when mixing both real and synthetic data, we provide an estimate of a maximal amount of synthetic data below which model collapse can eventually be avoided. Our theoretical conclusions are further supported by empirical validations.

1 Introduction

The large-scale adoption of large language models (e.g. ChatGPT (OpenAI, 2024)) will inevitably lead to enormous amounts of synthetic (generated) data “polluting” the original human-created web data. Since language models are trained on web data, this raises some concerns about the impact of this synthetic data on the next generations of LLMs. One can think of a train-generate loop where models from the current generation generate data that contaminate existing web data, and the next generation models are trained on this contaminated data. This loop was studied in several works (Shumailov et al., 2023; Alemohammad et al., 2023; Briesch et al., 2023) where the authors conclude that synthetic data generally hurts performance as the number of generate-train increases, and that (naturally) the impact on model performance is linked to the amount of real data in the training set. A particular phenomenon, coined model collapse (Shumailov et al., 2023), refers to the model’s tendency to produce limited or repetitive outputs making recursive training on such outputs forget about the tails of the original underlying distribution of real data. This was further studied in (Guo et al., 2023) where the authors show that recursive training on synthetic data leads to a “self-consuming” loop that affects linguistic diversity.

Intuitively, model collapse is a result of the distribution shift that occurs when training generative models recursively on synthetic data from previous generation models. Shumailov et al. (2023) have discussed two main sources of model collapse; 1) statistical approximation error: which is inherently related to the fact that generative models are trained on a finite number of samples, and therefore it is impossible that the learned model captures all the information about the original distribution. 2) functional approximation error: which results from the fact that the models are insufficiently expressive in real implementations, even if neural networks are known to be universal functional approximators from a theoretical standpoint. The authors provide further theoretical intuition to characterize the effect of these approximation errors, relying on simple mathematical models such as single-dimensional Gaussian distribution.

In this paper, we aim to provide a rigorous theoretical framework to understand the effects of recursive training with synthetic data. In particular, we focus on the statistical approximation error and introduce a simple next-token-prediction language model to characterize model collapse. Our model allows us to gain insights into the behaviour of the self-consuming train-generate loop leading to model collapse. From a theoretical standpoint, we consider two main recursive training scenarios:

  • •

    Fully Synthetic: Training with data sampled from the previous generation model.

  • •

    Partially Synthetic: Training with a mixture of data sampled from the previous generation model and original data.

We demonstrate that model collapse always occurs in the first scenario and characterize the rates at which it occurs. Furthermore, in the second scenario, we provide an upper bound on the sample size of generated data below which model collapse can eventually be attenuated. Our results are further confirmed through simulations of general scenarios with the introduced statistical model, as well as with realistic GPT2-style language models on real data. Our findings suggest that the amount of generated data should be considerably smaller compared to the original data to avoid model collapse.

Related work:

With the adoption of generative Large Language and Vision models, the amount of synthetic data on the web is growing at an unprecedented rate – see for example (del Rio-Chanona et al., 2023) where the authors conducted an empirical study of the amount of synthetic data via activity monitoring on Stack Overflow, and (Alemohammad et al., 2023) where the authors showed that a dataset used to train Stable Diffusion contains synthetic data (Schuhmann et al., 2022). In fact, practitioners are willingly using synthetic data to train next-generation models (Ben Allal et al., 2024; Gunasekar et al., 2023; Chen et al., 2024).

As we mentioned above, several works studied the recursive training loop where next-generation models are trained on synthetic data generated from previous-generation models. Shumailov et al. (2023) studied model collapse, a phenomenon that occurs in recursive training where the quality of model outputs tend to degrade by becoming e.g. repetitive. Similar phenomena were studied in (Alemohammad et al., 2023) where the authors call it Model Autophagy Disorder (MAD). Another empirical study by (Briesch et al., 2023) studied this same Self-Consuming phenomenon and observed that the degeneracy rate (naturally) depends on the number of fresh data in the training sample. In the same direction, several works showed that incorporating synthetic data in the training can hurt the performance of trained diffusion models (Bohacek & Farid, 2023; Martínez et al., 2023a; b).

Only a few works have tackled this question from a theoretical perspective. Shumailov et al. (2023) considered a simple recursive Gaussian distribution to provide an intuition as to why model collapse occurs, but no training is considered in that work. In (Fu et al., 2024), authors studied recursive training of diffusion models (generally used to learn distributions over images) and obtained an upper bound on the total variation distance between the distribution of the original data and that of the synthetic data after T𝑇T generations. Dohmatob et al. (2024b) studied the impact of synthetic data on scaling laws and, in a simple setting of linear regression, Dohmatob et al. (2024a) studied the behaviour of the test error of different generations and showed that a linear dependency of the degradation on generation number.

In this work, we are interested in characterizing the distribution shift in synthetic data generated with a language model, as the number of generations increases. We consider a linear Softmax classifier for next-token prediction and study the distribution of the learned conditional probabilities as the number of generations increases. The closest work to ours is (Fu et al., 2024) where the authors study the distribution of synthetic data generated by a diffusion model instead, whereas the statistical model we are considering is closer in spirit to the realm of language models.

The remainder of the paper is organized as follows. Section 2 presents our theoretical setup where we introduce our statistical model and the considered recursive training scenarios. Our main theoretical results are presented in Section 3. We further present some experiments in Section 4.1 to support our findings. Finally, Section 5 concludes the paper.

2.2 Recursive Training

In this section, we introduce the notations for recursive training. At generation m≥1𝑚1m\geq 1, suppose that we have samples {𝒚l(t)}lsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒚𝑡𝑙𝑙\{{\bm{y}}^{(t)}_{l}\}_{l} generated by some past models 𝒑(t)superscript𝒑𝑡{\bm{p}}^{(t)} for t∈{0,…,m−1}𝑡0…𝑚1t\in\{0,\ldots,m-1\} respectively. As such, similarly to (2), the model at generation m𝑚m expresses as

𝒑(m):=1n(m)​∑t=0m−1∑l=1nt(m)𝒚l(t).assignsuperscript𝒑𝑚1superscript𝑛𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑚1superscriptsubscript𝑙1subscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑚𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒚𝑡𝑙\displaystyle{\bm{p}}^{(m)}:=\frac{1}{n^{(m)}}\sum_{t=0}^{m-1}\sum_{l=1}^{n^{(m)}_{t}}{\bm{y}}^{(t)}_{l}. (5)

In other words, 𝒑(m)superscript𝒑𝑚{\bm{p}}^{(m)} is obtained by training the model on a mixture of real and synthetic data generated from previously trained models. Here, nt(m)subscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑚𝑡n^{(m)}_{t} stands for the number of samples used to train the m𝑚m-th generation model that are generated by model 𝒑(t)superscript𝒑𝑡{\bm{p}}^{(t)}, and n(m)=n0(m)+⋯+nm−1(m)superscript𝑛𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑚0⋯subscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑚𝑚1n^{(m)}=n^{(m)}_{0}+\cdots+n^{(m)}_{m-1} is the total number of training samples used to train 𝒑(m)superscript𝒑𝑚{\bm{p}}^{(m)}. Note that we do not generate samples from 𝒑=𝒑(0)𝒑superscript𝒑0{\bm{p}}={\bm{p}}^{(0)} but rather we are given a corpus {𝒚l(0)}lsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒚0𝑙𝑙\{{\bm{y}}^{(0)}_{l}\}_{l} which represent original data.

Note that by definition all the models 𝒑(m)superscript𝒑𝑚{\bm{p}}^{(m)} are unbiased, i.e. 𝔼​𝒑(m)=𝒑𝔼superscript𝒑𝑚𝒑\mathbb{E}{\bm{p}}^{(m)}={\bm{p}}, which means that they recover the original distribution in case of infinite sample sizes. However, in practical settings the sample sizes are finite, and therefore 𝒑(m)superscript𝒑𝑚{\bm{p}}^{(m)} may deviate from 𝒑𝒑{\bm{p}} since its variance can be large for small values of nt(m)superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑡𝑚n_{t}^{(m)}. In the remainder of the paper, we present analytical results to rigorously quantify the impact of sample sizes nt(m)subscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑚𝑡n^{(m)}_{t} on the variance of 𝒑(m)superscript𝒑𝑚{\bm{p}}^{(m)} and how they affect the learned distribution to eventually cause model collapse (Shumailov et al., 2023), a degenerative process affecting future generation models by either losing information about the tails of the initial distribution or inducing distribution shifts over generations.

Specifically, we aim to quantify the rate of such deterioration, and to this end, we introduce a stricter version of model collapse that we call total collapse and define as follows.

Definition 1 (Total Collapse).

We say that total collapse occurs in the recursive training process if 𝐩(m)superscript𝐩𝑚{\bm{p}}^{(m)} converges to some Dirac mass δisubscript𝛿𝑖\delta_{i} for some token i∈[s]𝑖delimited-[]𝑠i\in[s] as m𝑚m grows.

Total collapse refers to the case where, under recursive training, the trained model 𝒑(m)superscript𝒑𝑚{\bm{p}}^{(m)} completely loses information about the original distribution 𝒑𝒑{\bm{p}} over generations, leading to poor linguistic diversity.111Note that here we define total collapse with respect to a single pre-fixed context. This can be generalized to the event where total collapse occurs for all contexts. However, the theoretical analysis in this case would require more refined treatment of several statistical quantities to obtain uniform bounds over contexts. We leave this for future work. This phenomenon is illustrated in Figure 1 where we see convergence towards the vertices of the probability simplex, i.e. Dirac measures, over generations. With this definition of total collapse, we provide a quantitative analysis of two cases of recursive training:

  • •

    Fully Synthetic: Training with synthetic data from the last model. Each generation 𝒑(m)superscript𝒑𝑚{\bm{p}}^{(m)} is trained only on data generated by the previous model 𝒑(m−1)superscript𝒑𝑚1{\bm{p}}^{(m-1)}. More precisely, for some fixed n∈ℕ𝑛ℕn\in{\mathbb{N}} we let nt(m)=n⋅𝟙​{t=m−1}subscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑚𝑡⋅𝑛1𝑡𝑚1n^{(m)}_{t}=n\cdot\mathbb{1}\{t=m-1\} for all m≥1𝑚1m\geq 1 and 0≤t<m0𝑡𝑚0\leq t<m.

  • •

    Partially Synthetic: Training with a mixture of real and synthetic data from the last model. Each generation 𝒑(m)superscript𝒑𝑚{\bm{p}}^{(m)} is trained on a mixture of real data and synthetic data generated by the previous model 𝒑(m−1)superscript𝒑𝑚1{\bm{p}}^{(m-1)}. More precisely, for some fixed n∈ℕ𝑛ℕn\in{\mathbb{N}} we let n0(m)=Nsubscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑚0𝑁n^{(m)}_{0}=N, nm−1(m)=nsubscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑚𝑚1𝑛n^{(m)}_{m-1}=n and nt(m)=0subscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑚𝑡0n^{(m)}_{t}=0 for all m≥2𝑚2m\geq 2 and 0<t<m0𝑡𝑚0<t<m, and n0(1)=Nsubscriptsuperscript𝑛10𝑁n^{(1)}_{0}=N.

Fully Synthetic corresponds to the theoretical setting considered in (Shumailov et al., 2023). However, in that paper, only Gaussian distribution was analyzed instead of discrete distributions over all possible tokens as language models entail. We point out that this setting is unlikely to happen in real-world applications but serves as the worst-case scenario.

On the other hand, the Partially Synthetic setting is more realistic for future generation models as it corresponds to training on a mixture of real and synthetic data. We consider this setting to assess whether it is possible to avoid collapse by having a fraction of the original data in the training mixture. We answer this question positively in the next section. Moreover, we show through simulations in Section 4.1 that conclusions from our theoretical analysis on both Fully Synthetic and Partially Synthetic hold beyond these simple settings, such as training on a mixture of all generations or even using realistic transformer models.

3 Main Results

To investigate the model collapse phenomenon and the rate at which it occurs, we define the following statistical quantities that capture the randomness of 𝒑(m)superscript𝒑𝑚{\bm{p}}^{(m)}:

‖𝒑(m)‖∞:=maxi∈[s]⁡pi(m),σm:=‖𝒑(m)‖22=∑i=1spi(m)2andSm:=𝔼​[σm].formulae-sequenceformulae-sequenceassignsubscriptnormsuperscript𝒑𝑚subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑚𝑖assignsubscript𝜎𝑚superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscript𝒑𝑚22superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑠superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑚𝑖2assignandsubscript𝑆𝑚𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝜎𝑚\displaystyle\|{\bm{p}}^{(m)}\|_{\infty}:=\max_{i\in[s]}p^{(m)}_{i},\quad\sigma_{m}:=\|{\bm{p}}^{(m)}\|_{2}^{2}=\sum_{i=1}^{s}{p^{(m)}_{i}}^{2}\quad\text{and}\quad S_{m}:=\mathbb{E}[\sigma_{m}].

These quantities measure how far away 𝒑(m)superscript𝒑𝑚{\bm{p}}^{(m)} is from some Dirac mass (Total Collapse, Definition 1). Since the maximum value of all three quantities is 111, the closer they are to 111, the closer 𝒑(m)superscript𝒑𝑚{\bm{p}}^{(m)} is to some Dirac mass, and the less diverse 𝒑(m)superscript𝒑𝑚{\bm{p}}^{(m)} is as a language model. As such, ‖𝒑(m)‖∞subscriptnormsuperscript𝒑𝑚\|{\bm{p}}^{(m)}\|_{\infty} or σmsubscript𝜎𝑚\sigma_{m} being equal to 111 is equivalent to 𝒑(m)superscript𝒑𝑚{\bm{p}}^{(m)} being a Dirac mass which reflects total collapse. To quantify the distribution shift incurred by the aforementioned recursive training scenarios, we further consider the 111-norm222We point out that the 111-norm is twice the total variation distance ‖μ−ν‖TVsubscriptnorm𝜇𝜈TV\|\mu-\nu\|_{\text{TV}}, which is another commonly used metric for probability distributions and was considered by Fu et al. (2024) for studying model collapse in the case of diffusion models. between two distributions μ,ν∈ℝs𝜇𝜈superscriptℝ𝑠\mu,\nu\in\mathbb{R}^{s} defined by ‖μ−ν‖1:=∑i=1s|μ​(i)−ν​(i)|assignsubscriptnorm𝜇𝜈1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑠𝜇𝑖𝜈𝑖\|\mu-\nu\|_{1}:=\sum_{i=1}^{s}|\mu(i)-\nu(i)|.

We assume that the initial distribution 𝒑(0)superscript𝒑0{\bm{p}}^{(0)} is nontrivial, specifically S0<1subscript𝑆01S_{0}<1 and ‖𝒑(0)‖∞<1subscriptnormsuperscript𝒑01\|{\bm{p}}^{(0)}\|_{\infty}<1. Under this assumption, we provide results on the rate of total collapse and further quantify distribution shift under recursive training. All the proofs are presented in Appendix B.

3.1 Fully Synthetic: Training on synthetic data

We start by describing the recursive training process in which only synthetic data from the last generation model are used. This process can be viewed as a Markov chain on the set of probability measures Δs−1∩1n​ℕssuperscriptΔ𝑠11𝑛superscriptℕ𝑠\Delta^{s-1}\cap\frac{1}{n}\mathbb{N}^{s} on [s]delimited-[]𝑠[s] with denominator n𝑛n, where

Δs−1:={𝒗∈ℝs:v1+v2+⋯+vs=1,vi≥0​ for all ​i}assignsuperscriptΔ𝑠1conditional-set𝒗superscriptℝ𝑠formulae-sequencesubscript𝑣1subscript𝑣2⋯subscript𝑣𝑠1subscript𝑣𝑖0 for all 𝑖\Delta^{s-1}:=\{{\bm{v}}\in\mathbb{R}^{s}:v_{1}+v_{2}+\dots+v_{s}=1,v_{i}\geq 0\textrm{ for all }i\}

is the probability simplex. Since the probability of reaching δisubscript𝛿𝑖\delta_{i} is positive provided pi>0subscript𝑝𝑖0p_{i}>0, this random walk which starts at 𝒑(0)superscript𝒑0{\bm{p}}^{(0)} has absorbing states {δi:i∈[s]​ s.t. ​pi>0}conditional-setsubscript𝛿𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑠 s.t. subscript𝑝𝑖0\{\delta_{i}:i\in[s]\text{ s.t. }p_{i}>0\}. As a result, the random walk converges to one of the absorbing states almost surely (Kemeny et al., 1969), which means that total collapse is bound to happen in the Fully Synthetic setting.

To characterize the rate at which total collapse occurs, let us denote by T:=inf{t∈ℕ:‖𝒑(t)‖∞=1}≥1assign𝑇infimumconditional-set𝑡ℕsubscriptnormsuperscript𝒑𝑡11T:=\inf\{t\in{\mathbb{N}}:\|{\bm{p}}^{(t)}\|_{\infty}=1\}\geq 1 the random time at which the model first becomes a Dirac mass, and let ρm:=ℙ​(‖𝒑(m)‖∞=1)assignsubscript𝜌𝑚ℙsubscriptnormsuperscript𝒑𝑚1\rho_{m}:={\mathbb{P}}\left(\|{\bm{p}}^{(m)}\|_{\infty}=1\right) denote the probability that the m𝑚m-th generation has collapsed. Our first result, presented in Theorem 1, provides the rate of convergence via Smsubscript𝑆𝑚S_{m}, ρmsubscript𝜌𝑚\rho_{m} and 𝔼​[T]𝔼delimited-[]𝑇\mathbb{E}[T].

Theorem 1 (Control on Total Collapse).

Consider the Fully Synthetic setting and let s~:=|supp​(𝐩)|assign~𝑠supp𝐩\tilde{s}:=|\text{supp}({\bm{p}})| denote the support size of 𝐩𝐩{\bm{p}}, namely s~:=|{i∈[s]:pi>0}|assign~𝑠conditional-set𝑖delimited-[]𝑠subscript𝑝𝑖0\tilde{s}:=|\{i\in[s]:p_{i}>0\}|.

  1. 1.

    The expected sum of squared probabilities Smsubscript𝑆𝑚S_{m} is given by

    Sm=1−(1−1n)m​(1−S0).subscript𝑆𝑚1superscript11𝑛𝑚1subscript𝑆0S_{m}=1-\left(1-\frac{1}{n}\right)^{m}(1-S_{0}). (6)
  2. 2.

    The probability ρmsubscript𝜌𝑚\rho_{m} that total collapse has occurred by generation m𝑚m satisfies

    1−n​(1−S0)​(1−1/n)m≤ρm≤1−1−S01−1/s~​(1−1/n)m.1𝑛1subscript𝑆0superscript11𝑛𝑚subscript𝜌𝑚11subscript𝑆011~𝑠superscript11𝑛𝑚1-n(1-S_{0})(1-1/n)^{m}\leq\rho_{m}\leq 1-\frac{1-S_{0}}{1-1/\tilde{s}}(1-1/n)^{m}. (7)
  3. 3.

    The generation T𝑇T at which total collapse happens satisfies

    1+1−S01−1/s~​(n−1)≤𝔼​[T]≤1+(1−S0)​n​(n−1).11subscript𝑆011~𝑠𝑛1𝔼delimited-[]𝑇11subscript𝑆0𝑛𝑛11+\frac{1-S_{0}}{1-1/\tilde{s}}(n-1)\leq\mathbb{E}[T]\leq 1+(1-S_{0})n(n-1). (8)

In essence, Theorem 1 describes the behavior of 𝒑(m)superscript𝒑𝑚{\bm{p}}^{(m)} as a function of the model generation m𝑚m, the sample size n𝑛n, and the dispersion of the initial distribution S0subscript𝑆0S_{0}. Specifically, we draw the following observations:

  • •

    Effect of the number of generations m𝑚m: As m𝑚m increases, Smsubscript𝑆𝑚S_{m} and ρmsubscript𝜌𝑚\rho_{m} tend to 111 as per (6) and (7), making total collapse increasingly more likely. Note also that this dependence is exponential in m𝑚m, making total collapse in this case relatively fast.

  • •

    Effect of “synthetic” sample size n𝑛n: The smaller n𝑛n is, the more likely 𝒑(m)superscript𝒑𝑚{\bm{p}}^{(m)} is to have collapsed for a given generation m𝑚m as per the bounds on ρmsubscript𝜌𝑚\rho_{m} in (7), and the faster total collapse is expected to happen as suggested by (8). The dependence in this case is polynomial in n𝑛n.

  • •

    Effect of S0subscript𝑆0S_{0}: Larger values of S0subscript𝑆0S_{0} correspond to faster collapse as suggested by (8); namely, starting from an original distribution that is not diverse enough speeds up total collapse. The upper and lower bounds on 𝔼​[T]𝔼delimited-[]𝑇\mathbb{E}[T] are both linear in (1−S0)1subscript𝑆0(1-S_{0}).

We point out that when the number of contexts c𝑐c is large, the number of samples n𝑛n per context would be fairly small, which suggests that total collapse, given a single context, is expected to happen fairly quickly. The bounds on 𝔼​[T]𝔼delimited-[]𝑇\mathbb{E}[T] state that the expected collapse time is at least of order n𝑛n and at most of order n2superscript𝑛2n^{2}, though experiments (see Figure 2) suggest that the upper bound is not sharp and should be close to 𝒪​(n)𝒪𝑛{\mathcal{O}}(n) instead. On another note, we characterize below in Proposition 1 the limiting distribution as m𝑚m gets to infinity, which demonstrates the direction of total collapse.

Proposition 1.

In the Fully Synthetic case, we have ℙ​(limm→∞𝐩(m)=δi)=piℙsubscript→𝑚superscript𝐩𝑚subscript𝛿𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖\displaystyle{\mathbb{P}}\left(\lim_{m\to\infty}{\bm{p}}^{(m)}=\delta_{i}\right)=p_{i} for all i∈[s]𝑖delimited-[]𝑠i\in[s].

Proposition 1 describes the limiting distribution when total collapse occurs in terms of the initial probabilities pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i} over tokens. Specifically, the resulting Dirac mass δisubscript𝛿𝑖\delta_{i} is likely to be supported on some token i𝑖i with high initial probability pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}. This formally supports the description of early and late model collapse in Shumailov et al. (2023): In the early phase of recursive training, the tails of the original distribution disappear because the probability pj(m)subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑚𝑗p^{(m)}_{j} of outputting unlikely tokens j𝑗j (those j𝑗j’s for which pjsubscript𝑝𝑗p_{j} is small) will decrease as 𝒑(m)superscript𝒑𝑚{\bm{p}}^{(m)} converges to some Dirac mass δisubscript𝛿𝑖\delta_{i}. After many generations, all but one pj(m)subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑚𝑗p^{(m)}_{j} will go to 00, exhibiting late model collapse where all the randomness of the original distribution is lost.

3.2 Partially Synthetic: Handling model collapse with real data

As described in the previous section, total collapse is unavoidable when training solely on synthetic data. In this section, we consider the case in which real data is incorporated at each generation. In this case, 𝒑(m)superscript𝒑𝑚{\bm{p}}^{(m)} can be simply seen as a weighted average of 𝒑(1)superscript𝒑1{\bm{p}}^{(1)} and an estimate of 𝒑(m−1)superscript𝒑𝑚1{\bm{p}}^{(m-1)} with n𝑛n samples. We also assume that 𝒑(1)superscript𝒑1{\bm{p}}^{(1)} is nontrivial, thereby implying that, on average, 𝒑(m)superscript𝒑𝑚{\bm{p}}^{(m)} will not be a Dirac mass. In what follows, we quantify the variability in the data distribution across different generations, as well as the distribution drift ‖𝒑(m)−𝒑(1)‖1subscriptnormsuperscript𝒑𝑚superscript𝒑11\|{\bm{p}}^{(m)}-{\bm{p}}^{(1)}\|_{1} from the first-generation model. We particularly show that collapse can be avoided if enough real data is injected into the recursive training process.

Theorem 2 (Model Variation).

Consider the Partially Synthetic setting. For m≥1𝑚1m\geq 1 we have

Sm+1=1N​[1+2​α−(1−1N)​α​βm]1+(1+1/N)​α+(1−1N)​S01+(1+1/N)​α​[1+α−α​βmN],subscript𝑆𝑚11𝑁delimited-[]12𝛼11𝑁𝛼superscript𝛽𝑚111𝑁𝛼11𝑁subscript𝑆0111𝑁𝛼delimited-[]1𝛼𝛼superscript𝛽𝑚𝑁\displaystyle S_{m+1}=\dfrac{\frac{1}{N}\left[1+2\alpha-\left(1-\frac{1}{N}\right)\alpha\beta^{m}\right]}{1+(1+1/N)\alpha}+\dfrac{(1-\frac{1}{N})S_{0}}{1+(1+1/N)\alpha}\left[1+\alpha-\frac{\alpha\beta^{m}}{N}\right], (9)

where α:=nN+nassign𝛼𝑛𝑁𝑛\alpha:=\frac{n}{N+n} and β:=α​[(1+1N)​α−1N]assign𝛽𝛼delimited-[]11𝑁𝛼1𝑁\beta:=\alpha\left[(1+\frac{1}{N})\alpha-\frac{1}{N}\right].

Theorem 2 provides a control of the variance Smsubscript𝑆𝑚S_{m} in the Partially Synthetic setting. Essentially, when n≪Nmuch-less-than𝑛𝑁n\ll N, we have Sm≈1N+(1−1N)​S0≈S0subscript𝑆𝑚1𝑁11𝑁subscript𝑆0subscript𝑆0S_{m}\approx\frac{1}{N}+(1-\frac{1}{N})S_{0}\approx S_{0}, which is not surprising since the training data for each generation model are dominated by real data in this case. However, even when the number of synthetic data is much larger than the original dataset (i.e. n≫Nmuch-greater-than𝑛𝑁n\gg N), we have α≈1≈β𝛼1𝛽\alpha\approx 1\approx\beta and hence Sm+1≈1/N+(2+1/N)−1​(1−1/N)​(2−1/N)​S0subscript𝑆𝑚11𝑁superscript21𝑁111𝑁21𝑁subscript𝑆0S_{m+1}\approx 1/N+(2+1/N)^{-1}(1-1/N)(2-1/N)S_{0}, which approaches S0subscript𝑆0S_{0} for large N𝑁N.

To further refine our analysis, we present a result that directly controls the deviation 𝔼​‖𝒑(m)−𝒑(1)‖1𝔼subscriptnormsuperscript𝒑𝑚superscript𝒑11\mathbb{E}\|{\bm{p}}^{(m)}-{\bm{p}}^{(1)}\|_{1} between the conditional distributions from first and m𝑚m-th generations. This allows us to have a quantitative control over the distribution shift. When n𝑛n is sufficiently small, we have a sharper control over this deviation by exploiting the concentration results from (Mardia et al., 2020). Essentially, this allows us to estimate the maximum number of synthetic samples n𝑛n to ensure that the distribution 𝒑(m)superscript𝒑𝑚{\bm{p}}^{(m)} stays close to 𝒑(1)superscript𝒑1{\bm{p}}^{(1)}.

Theorem 3 (Model Deviation).

Consider the Partially Synthetic setting and define

Gn​(s):={C1​s​eC0​n2​eifC0e​n+2≤s;C1​s​(C0​ns)s/2ifC04​n+2≤s<C0e​n+2;(2s−2)ifs<C04​n+2,assignsubscript𝐺𝑛𝑠casessubscript𝐶1𝑠superscript𝑒subscript𝐶0𝑛2𝑒ifsubscript𝐶0𝑒𝑛2𝑠subscript𝐶1𝑠superscriptsubscript𝐶0𝑛𝑠𝑠2ifsubscript𝐶04𝑛2𝑠subscript𝐶0𝑒𝑛2superscript2𝑠2if𝑠subscript𝐶04𝑛2\displaystyle G_{n}(s):=\begin{cases}C_{1}se^{\frac{C_{0}n}{2e}}&\text{if}\quad\frac{C_{0}}{e}n+2\leq s;\\ C_{1}s\left(\frac{C_{0}n}{s}\right)^{s/2}&\text{if}\quad\frac{C_{0}}{4}n+2\leq s<\frac{C_{0}}{e}n+2;\\ (2^{s}-2)&\text{if}\quad s<\frac{C_{0}}{4}n+2,\end{cases} (10)

where C0=e32​π≈3.19subscript𝐶0superscript𝑒32𝜋3.19C_{0}=\frac{e^{3}}{2\pi}\approx 3.19 and C1=6​eπ3/2≈2.93subscript𝐶16𝑒superscript𝜋322.93C_{1}=\frac{6e}{\pi^{3/2}}\approx 2.93, and s𝑠s is the vocabulary size. Then, for m≥2𝑚2m\geq 2,

𝔼​‖𝒑(m)−𝒑(1)‖1<1N​π​n2​Gn​(s).𝔼subscriptnormsuperscript𝒑𝑚superscript𝒑111𝑁𝜋𝑛2subscript𝐺𝑛𝑠\mathbb{E}\|{\bm{p}}^{(m)}-{\bm{p}}^{(1)}\|_{1}<\frac{1}{N}\sqrt{\frac{\pi n}{2}}G_{n}(s).

We point out that the upper bound on the deviation 𝔼​‖𝒑(m)−𝒑(1)‖1𝔼subscriptnormsuperscript𝒑𝑚superscript𝒑11\mathbb{E}\|{\bm{p}}^{(m)}-{\bm{p}}^{(1)}\|_{1} is independent of the generation m𝑚m. Since the deviation from 𝒑(0)superscript𝒑0{\bm{p}}^{(0)} to 𝒑(1)superscript𝒑1{\bm{p}}^{(1)} is inevitable and independent of n𝑛n, we give the result in 𝔼​‖𝒑(m)−𝒑(1)‖1𝔼subscriptnormsuperscript𝒑𝑚superscript𝒑11\mathbb{E}\|{\bm{p}}^{(m)}-{\bm{p}}^{(1)}\|_{1}, from which 𝔼​‖𝒑(m)−𝒑(0)‖1𝔼subscriptnormsuperscript𝒑𝑚superscript𝒑01\mathbb{E}\|{\bm{p}}^{(m)}-{\bm{p}}^{(0)}\|_{1} can be estimated by the triangle inequality. Theorem 3 allows us to estimate the maximum number of synthetic samples n𝑛n that can be used if we want 𝒑(m)superscript𝒑𝑚{\bm{p}}^{(m)} to stay ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-close to 𝒑(1)superscript𝒑1{\bm{p}}^{(1)} in L1superscript𝐿1L^{1} norm. For example, when C0​n/e+2≤ssubscript𝐶0𝑛𝑒2𝑠C_{0}n/e+2\leq s, for any ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0 we can take

n≤2​π​e−2​min⁡[s−2,log⁡(2​π​N​ϵ6​e​s)]𝑛2𝜋superscript𝑒2𝑠22𝜋𝑁italic-ϵ6𝑒𝑠n\leq 2\pi e^{-2}\min\left[s-2,\log\left(\frac{\sqrt{2}\pi N\epsilon}{6es}\right)\right] (11)

in order for 𝔼​‖𝒑(m)−𝒑(1)‖1𝔼subscriptnormsuperscript𝒑𝑚superscript𝒑11\mathbb{E}\|{\bm{p}}^{(m)}-{\bm{p}}^{(1)}\|_{1} to be less than ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. In other words, to ensure small L1superscript𝐿1L^{1} deviation n𝑛n should be taken to be logarithmic in the ratio N​ϵ/s𝑁italic-ϵ𝑠N\epsilon/s, which highlights that the amount of synthetic data should be exponentially smaller compared to real data in order to ensure that 𝒑(m)superscript𝒑𝑚{\bm{p}}^{(m)} remains close to 𝒑(1)superscript𝒑1{\bm{p}}^{(1)}. We show through simulations the effect of the sample size n𝑛n and the initial distribution 𝒑𝒑{\bm{p}}. In Figure 3, we show that if we fix the initial distribution and increase the amount of synthetic data n𝑛n, the dispersion σmsubscript𝜎𝑚\sigma_{m} stays relatively constant while the distribution drift ‖𝒑(m)−𝒑(1)‖1subscriptnormsuperscript𝒑𝑚superscript𝒑11\|{\bm{p}}^{(m)}-{\bm{p}}^{(1)}\|_{1} increases. In contrast, when we fix n𝑛n and increase the values of S0subscript𝑆0S_{0}, σmsubscript𝜎𝑚\sigma_{m} increases but ‖𝒑(m)−𝒑(1)‖1subscriptnormsuperscript𝒑𝑚superscript𝒑11\|{\bm{p}}^{(m)}-{\bm{p}}^{(1)}\|_{1} actually decreases as depicted in Figure 4. This behavior can be explained by Theorem 4 in Appendix B, which is more general than Theorem 3 in the sense that it captures the dependence of 𝔼​‖𝒑(m)−𝒑(1)‖1𝔼subscriptnormsuperscript𝒑𝑚superscript𝒑11\mathbb{E}\|{\bm{p}}^{(m)}-{\bm{p}}^{(1)}\|_{1} on the randomness of 𝒑𝒑{\bm{p}} and hence provides a sharper bound on the expected deviation.

4 Experiments

4.1 Transformer-based Models

To support our findings in a realistic setting, we conduct experiments with a decoder-only generative model for text generation. For this model, we consider the aforementioned Fully Synthetic and Partially Synthetic settings using the model parameters in Appendix C. We consider a simple character-level tokenizer using the tiny Shakespeare dataset333https://raw.githubusercontent.com/karpathy/char-rnn/master/data/tinyshakespeare/input.txt yielding a vocabulary of size s=65𝑠65s=65. We first train a model for 200020002000 iterations on this dataset and consider the trained model as the ground-truth distribution 𝒑(0)superscript𝒑0{\bm{p}}^{(0)}. The next-generation models are trained recursively using the exact same architecture and training parameters. This setting allows us to reduce the effect of functional approximation error thereby focusing only on the effect of statistical approximation error.

The results of these experiments are summarized in Figure 5. The top left plot therein depicts the deviation ‖𝒑(m)−𝒑(1)‖1subscriptnormsuperscript𝒑𝑚superscript𝒑11\|{\bm{p}}^{(m)}-{\bm{p}}^{(1)}\|_{1} which is averaged over 300300300 random contexts generated by the ground-truth generative model 𝒑(0)superscript𝒑0{\bm{p}}^{(0)}. From this plot, we clearly see that ‖𝒑(m)−𝒑(1)‖1subscriptnormsuperscript𝒑𝑚superscript𝒑11\|{\bm{p}}^{(m)}-{\bm{p}}^{(1)}\|_{1} diverges over generations in the Fully Synthetic setting, while mixing with real data ensures stability over generations.

The effect of synthetic data is further noticed in the validation loss of the next-generation models where we see an overfitting effect in the Fully Synthetic setting. We point out that this effect might also be associated with the functional approximation error and was rigorously studied by Dohmatob et al. (2024a) in the case of linear regression, where the authors have shown that synthetic data affect the usual scaling laws. We believe that similar conclusions can be obtained with our statistical model by incorporating the functional approximation error, this can be achieved for instance by supposing that the context embeddings 𝒆isubscript𝒆𝑖{\bm{e}}_{i}’s are high-dimensional Gaussian vectors instead of canonical vectors, thereby introducing the embedding dimension as a parameter controlling model complexity.

4.2 Additional Experiments with the Statistical Model

To further investigate and demonstrate the generality of our theoretical findings, we present empirical results on two more scenarios that better represent recursive training in real-world settings, as follows:

  • •

    Most Recent Models: Each generation p(m)superscript𝑝𝑚p^{(m)} is trained on synthetic data from the most recent K𝐾K models for a fixed window size K𝐾K. More precisely, for some fixed n∈ℕ𝑛ℕn\in{\mathbb{N}} we let nt(m)=⌊n/K⌋⋅𝟙​{max⁡(0,m−K)≤t≤m−1}subscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑚𝑡⋅𝑛𝐾10𝑚𝐾𝑡𝑚1n^{(m)}_{t}=\lfloor n/K\rfloor\cdot\mathbb{1}\{\max(0,m-K)\leq t\leq m-1\} for all m≥1𝑚1m\geq 1. When K=1𝐾1K=1, this case degenerates to the Fully Synthetic setting.

  • •

    Randomly Sampled Data: Each generation p(m)superscript𝑝𝑚p^{(m)} is trained on a mixture of synthetic data from possibly all the previous models and the real data. More precisely, the m𝑚m-th generation model is trained on n=n0(m)+⋯+nm−1(m)𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑛0𝑚⋯superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑚1𝑚n=n_{0}^{(m)}+\cdots+n_{m-1}^{(m)} samples with

    nt(m):=∑i=1n𝟙​{gi=t},(t=0,⋯,m−1),assignsubscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑚𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛1subscript𝑔𝑖𝑡𝑡0⋯𝑚1n^{(m)}_{t}:=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{1}\{g_{i}=t\},\quad(t=0,\cdots,m-1),

    samples from the t𝑡t-th generation, where {gi}i∈[n]subscriptsubscript𝑔𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑛\{g_{i}\}_{i\in[n]} are independent and uniformly distributed on {0,1,…​m−1}01…𝑚1\{0,1,\ldots m-1\} indexing previous-generation models. This setting describes the scenario where data generated by all past models are mixed in a pool from which the training data for the next generation is collected.

Experiments for these two cases are shown in Figure 6. Column 111 corresponds to Fully Synthetic, columns 222 and 333 for Most Recent Models, and column 444 shows the case of Randomly Sampled Data. As we can see, when the window size K𝐾K is increased, total collapse is delayed but still eventually happens. Observe that there are multiple visible horizontal yellow lines in the second row for window size 111. This is because 𝒑(m)superscript𝒑𝑚{\bm{p}}^{(m)} can converge to any of the Dirac masses δisubscript𝛿𝑖\delta_{i} provided pi>0subscript𝑝𝑖0p_{i}>0 by Proposition 1. A similar phenomenon can be observed in the second and third columns. On the other hand, in column 444 the model does deteriorate but the deviation plateaus very quickly. In particular, the 100100100 runs produce only one Dirac mass over the span of 500500500 generations, suggesting that randomly sampling from all the past models is qualitatively different from sampling from the most recent K𝐾K models with a fixed K𝐾K. We remark that for K>1𝐾1K>1, even if p(m)superscript𝑝𝑚p^{(m)} is some Dirac mass, p(m+1)superscript𝑝𝑚1p^{(m+1)} could still regain randomness from models before generation m𝑚m, but with a fixed window size all the randomness eventually disappears.

5 Discussions & Conclusion

In this paper, we studied model collapse in language models through a simple statistical model. We provided theoretical analysis when training with only synthetic data and when adding real data from the original distribution. Our results demonstrate that model collapse always happens when the model is training solely on synthetic data, whereas controlling deviation from the initial distribution requires careful choice of the amount of synthetic data to inject in the training set. We also provided experiments showing that these findings extend beyond the simple theoretical settings.

Our current results describe only the statistical approximation error since all generation models are unbiased in our theoretical framework. However, as we discussed in the previous section, this framework can be extended to account for the functional approximation error by considering high-dimension Gaussian vectors as context embeddings instead of canonical vectors. Another possible extension is to study the effect of in-context learning (Wu et al., 2023) on model collapse, which is a key feature of transformer-based models.

Despite the simple setting of our current investigation, we believe that it lays the groundwork for better understanding and mitigation of model collapse in language models, thereby opening the way for the development of more general theoretical frameworks to study next-generation language models dynamics.

Appendix A Technical Lemma

For completeness, we include the concentration results from (Mardia et al., 2020) which we used to prove Theorem 3. For a probability distribution 𝒑𝒑{\bm{p}} on [s]delimited-[]𝑠[s] define

π𝒑:=maxA⊆[s]⁡min⁡{𝒑​(A),1−𝒑​(A)}assignsubscript𝜋𝒑subscript𝐴delimited-[]𝑠𝒑𝐴1𝒑𝐴\pi_{\bm{p}}:=\max_{A\subseteq[s]}\min\{{\bm{p}}(A),1-{\bm{p}}(A)\} (12)

and notice that π𝒑≤12subscript𝜋𝒑12\pi_{\bm{p}}\leq\frac{1}{2}. Define the function φ:[0,1/2)→ℝ:𝜑→012ℝ\varphi:[0,1/2)\to{\mathbb{R}} by

φ​(x):=11−2​x​log⁡1−xxassign𝜑𝑥112𝑥1𝑥𝑥\varphi(x):=\frac{1}{1-2x}\log\frac{1-x}{x}

and extend φ𝜑\varphi by continuity to φ​(1/2):=2assign𝜑122\varphi(1/2):=2. Observe that φ𝜑\varphi is strictly decreasing and 2≤φ​(x)<∞2𝜑𝑥2\leq\varphi(x)<\infty. The following Lemma concerns the concentration of empirical distribution which captures the dependence on the sample size n𝑛n, dimension s𝑠s as well as the structure of the underlying probability distribution via φ​(π𝒑)𝜑subscript𝜋𝒑\varphi(\pi_{\bm{p}}).

Lemma 1.

Let p𝑝p be a probability distribution on [s]delimited-[]𝑠[s] and p^^𝑝\hat{p} be the associated empirical distribution obtained from n𝑛n samples. Then for ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0 we have

ℙ​(‖𝒑^−𝒑‖1≥ϵ)≤exp⁡(−n​φ​(π𝒑)​ϵ24)​Gn​(s),ℙsubscriptnorm^𝒑𝒑1italic-ϵ𝑛𝜑subscript𝜋𝒑superscriptitalic-ϵ24subscript𝐺𝑛𝑠{\mathbb{P}}\left(\|\hat{{\bm{p}}}-{\bm{p}}\|_{1}\geq\epsilon\right)\leq\exp\left(-\frac{n\varphi(\pi_{\bm{p}})\epsilon^{2}}{4}\right)G_{n}(s),

where C0=e32​πsubscript𝐶0superscript𝑒32𝜋C_{0}=\frac{e^{3}}{2\pi}, C1=6​eπ3/2subscript𝐶16𝑒superscript𝜋32C_{1}=\frac{6e}{\pi^{3/2}} and

Gn​(s)={C1​s​(C0​n/s)s/2 if ​C0​n4+2≤s≤C0​ne+2;C1​s​eC0​n2​e if ​C0​ne+2≤s;(2s−2) if ​s≤C0​n4+2.subscript𝐺𝑛𝑠casessubscript𝐶1𝑠superscriptsubscript𝐶0𝑛𝑠𝑠2 if subscript𝐶0𝑛42𝑠subscript𝐶0𝑛𝑒2subscript𝐶1𝑠superscript𝑒subscript𝐶0𝑛2𝑒 if subscript𝐶0𝑛𝑒2𝑠superscript2𝑠2 if 𝑠subscript𝐶0𝑛42G_{n}(s)=\begin{cases}C_{1}s\left(C_{0}n/s\right)^{s/2}&\text{ if }\frac{C_{0}n}{4}+2\leq s\leq\frac{C_{0}n}{e}+2;\\ C_{1}se^{\frac{C_{0}n}{2e}}&\text{ if }\frac{C_{0}n}{e}+2\leq s;\\ (2^{s}-2)&\text{ if }s\leq\frac{C_{0}n}{4}+2.\end{cases} (13)

The upper bound

ℙ​(‖𝒑^−𝒑‖1)≤(2s−2)​exp⁡(−n​φ​(π𝒑)​ϵ24)ℙsubscriptnorm^𝒑𝒑1superscript2𝑠2𝑛𝜑subscript𝜋𝒑superscriptitalic-ϵ24{\mathbb{P}}(\|\hat{{\bm{p}}}-{\bm{p}}\|_{1})\leq(2^{s}-2)\exp\left(-\frac{n\varphi(\pi_{\bm{p}})\epsilon^{2}}{4}\right)

in fact holds for all values of s𝑠s and n𝑛n (Weissman et al., 2003), but this bound is very poor when s/n𝑠𝑛s/n is large, which is commonly the case for language models. Lemma 1 provides an improvement in the regime of small sample size n≲sless-than-or-similar-to𝑛𝑠n\lesssim s.

Proof of Proposition 1.

Proof of Theorem 4.

Since all generations share the same original data source, we can write

𝒑(k+1)=NN+n​𝒑(1)+nN+n​𝒑(k)^,where𝒑(k)^=1n​∑i=1n𝒚i(k)formulae-sequencesuperscript𝒑𝑘1𝑁𝑁𝑛superscript𝒑1𝑛𝑁𝑛^superscript𝒑𝑘where^superscript𝒑𝑘1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝒚𝑘𝑖{\bm{p}}^{(k+1)}=\frac{N}{N+n}{\bm{p}}^{(1)}+\frac{n}{N+n}\widehat{{\bm{p}}^{(k)}},\quad\text{where}\quad\widehat{{\bm{p}}^{(k)}}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}{\bm{y}}^{(k)}_{i} (17)

and {𝒚i(k)}i=1,…,nsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒚𝑘𝑖𝑖1…𝑛\{{\bm{y}}^{(k)}_{i}\}_{i=1,...,n} are i.i.d. multinomial with parameter 𝒑(k)superscript𝒑𝑘{\bm{p}}^{(k)} and one trial (k≥1)𝑘1(k\geq 1). This gives

𝒑(k+1)−𝒑(1)=nN+n​[𝒑(k)^−𝒑(1)],superscript𝒑𝑘1superscript𝒑1𝑛𝑁𝑛delimited-[]^superscript𝒑𝑘superscript𝒑1\displaystyle{\bm{p}}^{(k+1)}-{\bm{p}}^{(1)}=\frac{n}{N+n}\left[\widehat{{\bm{p}}^{(k)}}-{\bm{p}}^{(1)}\right],

and applying the triangle inequality yields

‖𝒑(k+1)−𝒑(1)‖1subscriptnormsuperscript𝒑𝑘1superscript𝒑11\displaystyle\|{\bm{p}}^{(k+1)}-{\bm{p}}^{(1)}\|_{1} =nN+n​‖𝒑(k)^−𝒑(1)‖1≤nN+n​‖𝒑(k)^−𝒑(k)‖1+nN+n​‖𝒑(k)−𝒑(1)‖1.absent𝑛𝑁𝑛subscriptnorm^superscript𝒑𝑘superscript𝒑11𝑛𝑁𝑛subscriptnorm^superscript𝒑𝑘superscript𝒑𝑘1𝑛𝑁𝑛subscriptnormsuperscript𝒑𝑘superscript𝒑11\displaystyle=\frac{n}{N+n}\left\|\widehat{{\bm{p}}^{(k)}}-{\bm{p}}^{(1)}\right\|_{1}\leq\frac{n}{N+n}\left\|\widehat{{\bm{p}}^{(k)}}-{\bm{p}}^{(k)}\right\|_{1}+\frac{n}{N+n}\left\|{\bm{p}}^{(k)}-{\bm{p}}^{(1)}\right\|_{1}.

From Lemma 1, we have

∎

Proof of Theorem 3.

Theorem 3 is an immediate consequence of Theorem 4 by replacing φ𝜑\varphi with its minimum value 222. ∎

Appendix C Architecture & training parameters for GPT2 experiments

We consider that all generation models have GPT2-type444https://github.com/karpathy/nanoGPT vanilla architecture which is a decoder-only generative model with the configuration and training parameters as summarized in Table 1. These parameters were chosen to achieve the best validation loss when training the first-generation model on data produced by ground-truth generative model 𝒑(0)superscript𝒑0{\bm{p}}^{(0)} as defined in Section 4.1.
